> So I recon phenotype comparison can be useful over and above plain 
> genome comparison. It's a bit of a concocted scenario but there it is.

I outlined in a previous mail my simulations where I let the agents 
decide on what they thought was sexually attractive, and how that gave 
rise to child-eaters. Child-eaters have many children, because a lot of 
the energy they spend on having children is regained when they eat their 
offspring. But as the child eaters quickly took over the population, it 
would quickly be wiped out. Lots of fun! Die, child-eaters, die!

I also tried sexual selection, where the sex of the offspring was 
determined genetically (not 50-50). As you may have guessed, being a 
male turned out to be very popular, because of the amount of energy 
needed for each child (tiny compared to that of the female). The 
population became heavily dominated by filandering males, and thus the 
population died out. My papa was a rolling stone...

Population dynamics is a delicate thing, and great fun to play with.

cheers,
m
